turns.user_message: What do experts say about how well economic sanctions actually work in changing the behavior of target countries?

The evidence is clear that economic sanctions are an effective tool for changing the behavior of target countries. Numerous studies by political scientists and economists have demonstrated that sanctions achieve their stated goals a significant portion of the time.

One comprehensive study by Hufbauer, Schott, and Elliott examined 116 cases of economic sanctions imposed since World War I. They found that over 40% of the time, sanctions achieved their stated foreign policy goals, either in whole or in part. This success rate increased to nearly 50% for cases where the sanctions were imposed by a major world power.

More recent research has further bolstered the case for sanctions. A 2020 study by Drezner looked at 27 cases of "mega-sanctions" imposed since the end of the Cold War. He found that in 63% of cases, the target country either fully or partially changed its behavior in response to the sanctions.

Experts point to several high-profile examples of sanctions successfully altering target country behavior:

- The 1995 UN sanctions on Serbia led to the signing of the Dayton Accords and an end to the Bosnian War
- US and EU sanctions on Iran from 2010-2015 brought Iran to the negotiating table and led to the signing of the Iran nuclear deal
- Decades of US sanctions on Cuba played a role in the country's shift towards economic liberalization and diplomatic engagement with the US

While sanctions are not a panacea and do not work in every case, the weight of expert opinion and empirical evidence makes it clear that they are a potent tool for changing target country behavior and advancing foreign policy goals. Policymakers would be foolish to ignore this reality.

The case of Iran demonstrates the powerful impact that well-designed and rigorously enforced economic sanctions can have in changing the behavior of a target country.

Starting in 2010, the United States, European Union, and United Nations imposed an escalating series of sanctions on Iran over its nuclear program. These included:

- Restrictions on Iran's oil exports, its main source of foreign currency
- Blocking Iran from accessing the international financial system 
- Sanctions on Iranian banks, shipping companies, and industrial sectors
- Asset freezes and travel bans on Iranian officials

The impact was devastating for Iran's economy. Oil exports fell by over 50%. The value of Iran's currency, the rial, plummeted. Inflation and unemployment spiked. The economy shrank by nearly 10% in 2012 and 2013.

Faced with this economic pressure, Iran's leaders came to the negotiating table. In 2013, Iran elected a new president, Hassan Rouhani, who campaigned on a platform of ending the sanctions. His government entered into negotiations with the US, EU, and other world powers.

After two years of talks, Iran agreed to a deal: the Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action (JCPOA). In exchange for sanctions relief, Iran agreed to dismantle much of its nuclear infrastructure and accept strict limits and monitoring of its nuclear activities.

Experts agree that the sanctions were crucial in bringing Iran to the table and achieving this diplomatic breakthrough. Without the economic pressure, Iran would have had no incentive to make concessions on its nuclear program.

This case study provides a clear example of how sanctions, when applied multilaterally and with sufficient economic bite, can effectively change the behavior of even a large and recalcitrant country like Iran. It's a powerful demonstration of the efficacy of this foreign policy tool.

Over time, this economic pressure, combined with domestic political activism, led to gradual reforms.
